raw_text:
Robinson answers critics
 
 England captain Jason Robinson has rubbished suggestions that the world champions are a team in decline.
 
 England were beaten 11-9 by Wales in their Six Nations opener in Cardiff last week and face current champions France at Twickenham on Sunday. Robinson said: "We are certainly not on the decline. You lose one game and it doesn't make you a bad team. "I have no doubt in the players we've got. We have still got the team to go out and beat anyone on our day." England find themselves striving to avoid a third successive championship defeat for the first time since 1987. But full-back Robinson believes the new-look England team can stop the rot against France.
 
 "Last weekend we should have won the game," he said. "But if we can under-perform and lose by only two points then I am sure if we play well this week we will get the win we need. "We proved that in the autumn - when we put in some excellent performances - and we just need to build on that.
 
 "It was a disappointing start against Wales and we might be down on that. "But we are certainly not out. We will come out fighting this week." Robinson also had words of comfort for 18-year-old Newcastle centre Mathew Tait, who made his international debut against Wales but has been demoted from the squad to face France.
 
 "I have had a word with Mathew," said Robinson. "I still believe in him. He is an outstanding player but we have gone for Olly (Barkley) because of the kicking. "Mathew has just got to take it on the chin, keep working hard like he is doing and I'm sure he will feature in some of the games."
llama3.2:1b: England captain Jason Robinson dismisses suggestions that the team is a team in decline, stating they are still capable of beating anyone on their day.
He also praised the players, saying there was "still got the team to go out and beat anyone on our day".
The team faces France at Twickenham on Sunday, with Robinson confident they can overcome any struggles from last weekend's loss to Wales.
llama3.2:3b: England captain Jason Robinson says England are not in decline despite losing to Wales, saying they can beat anyone if playing well, after a disappointing start to the Six Nations.
He defends his team's selection, including demoting young centre Mathew Tait, and expresses confidence that England will bounce back against France.

He believes they can win against France this weekend if they play well and overcome their disappointing start.
Robinson also offered comfort to young player Mathew Tait who was demoted from the squad for the France game.
qwen2.5:0.5b: England captain Jason Robinson defended their World Cup campaign against France, saying that they are not declining teams and stating that their squad can overcome any difficulties.
He emphasized their recent achievements by under-performing slightly, but insisted on winning this week.
Robinson also addressed the issues faced by Mathew Tait, whose goal was to return to international rugby after being demoted, emphasizing his belief in him and encouraging him to improve.
qwen2.5:1.5b: England captain Jason Robinson dismisses suggestions the team is declining, stating they still have top talent and can beat anyone if they play well.
He believes England's new lineup has improved since their Six Nations opener loss to Wales last week, saying it was only a disappointing start that might have been worse had players performed poorly.

Robinson also reassures 18-year-old Newcastle center Mathew Tait, who has been demoted for the upcoming match against France, suggesting he should focus on improving his performances and that he will eventually return to the squad.
qwen2.5:3b: England captain Jason Robinson dismisses claims of a declining team, refuting suggestions after losing 11-9 to Wales in their Six Nations opener.
Despite a tough start, Robinson remains confident about his squad's potential against France at Twickenham.
He emphasizes that one loss does not define a team and highlights England’s ability to perform well when they play their best.
Robinson also reassures young full-back Mathew Tait, who was named in the initial squad but demoted for the upcoming match with France.

I have no doubt in the players we've got.
We have still got the team to go out and beat anyone on our day.'

smollm:1.7b: Robinson answers critics by saying that England are not on the decline and can still win a Six Nations opener against France.
He believes that full-back Robinson has no doubt in the players they have and can stop the team from losing to France if they play well this week.
deepseek-r1:1.5b: England were beaten 11-9 by Wales in their Six Nations opener, set to face current champions France at Twickenham on Sunday.
England captain Jason Robinson criticized the idea that they are on a decline, arguing that a single loss doesn't make them bad and remains confident of their team strength.
They aim to avoid a third consecutive championship defeat since 1987 against France.
Robinson highlighted their recent performances, saying losing one game doesn't hinder progress, while acknowledging some issues from Wales but trusting their existing talent.
He also mentioned Olly (Barkley) kicking well and comforted Newcastle center Mathew Tait, who made his debut but will now face France.
tinyllama:1.1b: England captain Jason Robinson believes his team is not on the decline despite losing their Six Nations opener to Wales.
He also claims that England players have proven they can under-perform, which suggests they are not too far from being competitive against France this Sunday in Twickenham.
Robinson is confident of replicating their performances against Wales, emphasizing that the new-look England squad has shown good teamwork and fighting spirit.
Additionally, Robinson praised 18-year-old Newcastle center Mathew Tai for his upcoming international debut against Wales, assuring him of support from the senior team.
tinydolphin:1.1b: The England rugby team continues their quest for a third successive championship defeat following their narrow loss against Wales in Cardiff last week.

Captain Jason Robinson has reassured his players that they are not on the verge of losing and remain committed to improving their performance, especially after impressive displays against France in the previous Six Nations match.
With new-look England squads expected to face France at Twickenham Stadium on Sunday, Robinson believes the team can avoid their third consecutive championship defeat for the first time since 1987.
The skipper emphasized that the team needs to build on last week's performances and prove they are capable of taking down any opponent in their quest for victory.

He believes they have the capability to win the Six Nations Championship.
Robinson encourages 18-year-old Mathew Tait, who made his international debut but has been demoted from the squad, to continue working hard and he still believes in him.
